item.title: State homeless statsitics
item.description: With President Trump threatening federal intervention in California’s homeless crisis, it’s a good time to look at which state’s actually have the worst rates of homelessness. The surprise is that he has bigger problems closer to home, regardless of whether you’re talking about the White House or his Manhattan apartment. homeless_2018 %>% select(state, homeless_pct) %>% datatable(colnames=c('State',"Percent of population in 2018 that was homeless")) %>% formatPercentage(2, digits=2) {"

item.title: Random stuff on Bayes' Theorem
item.description: Intro Just some general notes as I try to learn how to use Bayes statistics. Take everything with a large grain of salt since there’s a reasonable chance I’ll get some of it wrong. The underlying idea is that the Bayes’ Theorem allows you to refine your grasp on reality by using new evidence to modify your understanding. Terminology: P(A): probability of Event A. P(B): probability of Event B.
